ht. And you

on

urse,   you could have that somebody is teaching

if I am somebody is

then q should be a friend of p. So,   then we have a graph like this, where now 
technically speaking, we have arrows representing   pairs in both dir

ections. So, we have an arrow 
from P to Q, saying that Q is a friend of P,   and we have an arrow from Q to P, saying

ignore them and draw only a single edge.
 
  S

o, formally, a graph is a set of vertices, those

it says some pairs

e have.

ric. So,   we have edges between two pairs in both directions

onnecting

ns. So, if you

iate nodes.

when we are

relation. So, we start for instance here.

And then we come here. So, this is technically   a sequ

ence of edges, each of which extends the

respect the arrows

. So, if I have, for instance,   an airline route, so this is a typical thing that

at these are some flights

take a   sequence of edges starting at V9, and reach V0.

sequence of flights, in this case, 1, 2, 3, 4,   5 flights to get from Madurai to Delhi.

happen that things are reachable,   it could happen that things are not reachable. So,

ad741482-e201-487b-8efd-042ca40a4e63.chunk:
if they are reachable, then one of the questions   that we might ask is among all the different

ontext 
that you might ask about reachability.

instance, if you take this edge from V4

from everywhere to everywhere because   earlier, you could go directly from V3 to V4.
But now, you can still do the same thing b

y going   around. So, if you want the what is now missing is

can still go from V3 to V6, V6 to V5, V5 to V7,   and V7 to V4. So, the ability to go from V

d709c282-70bc-4922-85a0-ec2870f71c6a.title: Introduction to Graphs
d709c282-70bc-4922-85a0-ec2870f71c6a.chunk:
3 to 
V4 has not changed, it has become a little more   tedious, but it is not impossible. So, this graph,

On the other hand, supposing we take this edge   between V4

and V0 and we make it in a single

can go back to V0, but I can go nowhe

50231cfb-e4f0-45c9-b9c3-22ba7289f9b1.chunk:
re else. So,   if I am now in this upper triangle of V0, V1, and

s connected

  So, reachability is not the only kind of question

and solved as graphs. So, for instance, here   i

4cdcc993-54de-444a-9de5-26a6e77604cd.title: Introduction to Graphs
4cdcc993-54de-444a-9de5-26a6e77604cd.chunk:
s a problem which superficially does not seem to 
require graphs, which is to colour a map properly.   So, when we colour a map properly, we want to 
neighbouring states or to neighbouring countries,   which share a border to have different colours.
So, on

45feb05b-c85a-4bb3-9571-74198b778700.title: Introduction to Graphs
45feb05b-c85a-4bb3-9571-74198b778700.chunk:
e of the questions that you can ask is how   many colours do we need. So, to transfer this to 
a graph problem, what we do is we first create a   vertex for every state that needs to be coloured. 
And now we want to express this constraint that   neighbour

ddb6645f-cc56-4cbc-8b57-2f5758e4dd56.title: Introduction to Graphs
ddb6645f-cc56-4cbc-8b57-2f5758e4dd56.chunk:
ing states should have different colours. 
So, we have to capture this neighbouring relation.   So, we do that by connecting them together. 
So, we attach an edge between every pair of   states, which shares a border.
So, now we have a graph. And now what

ea04aa6b-026b-4813-910b-939c6da49c42.title: Introduction to Graphs
ea04aa6b-026b-4813-910b-939c6da49c42.chunk:
is   our constraint, our constraint is we must assign a 
colour to every one of these black dots such that   if two black dots are connected by an 
edge, they must have different colours.   So, we must assign colours to nodes so that 
the endpoints of an a

3298403d-50d4-4b51-9883-8310a4a88c7b.title: Introduction to Graphs
3298403d-50d4-4b51-9883-8310a4a88c7b.chunk:
ge have different colours,   you cannot have a green on one side and the 
green on the other side, because that would   mean two neighbouring states have the same colour. 
So, this is called the map colouring problem.
  But notice that by coming up with th

6a3090ab-82bd-48c3-a440-0836d27832db.title: Introduction to Graphs
6a3090ab-82bd-48c3-a440-0836d27832db.chunk:
is graph 
representation, we have abstracted the problem   so that we are now no longer worried about the 
shapes of the states, the sizes of the states, the   kind of orientation of the boundary, how much of 
a boundary do they share? All we are intereste

fb0e1f45-9d00-48b9-9bca-0e9ea88ce945.title: Introduction to Graphs
fb0e1f45-9d00-48b9-9bca-0e9ea88ce945.chunk:
d   in is this picture, which is, what are the 
underlying states and how are they connected?
  And once we have this, it does not even need 
to respect that true physical geography. So,   I can take some of these nodes and move them 
aside, I can make the

f77ba41c-cb06-450e-80d9-82fefa702c92.title: Introduction to Graphs
f77ba41c-cb06-450e-80d9-82fefa702c92.chunk:
graph look different   superficially, without changing the underlying 
nature that is relevant to the problem namely,   which points are neighbours 
of which other points.
 
  So, this is called the graph colouring problem. 
So, we are given a graph and w

6275d218-29ed-4200-8886-f5d167aac9a9.title: Introduction to Graphs
6275d218-29ed-4200-8886-f5d167aac9a9.chunk:
e are given a set   of colours. And what we want to do is assign 
a colour to every vertex such that no pair of   adjacent vertices, there is no vertices which are 
connected by an edge have the same colour. So,   this is what is saying, if u, v are edges

5fc4ad6e-1a43-4d5f-84b7-6ad30f870c4c.title: Introduction to Graphs
5fc4ad6e-1a43-4d5f-84b7-6ad30f870c4c.chunk:
in a, 
if u, v is an edge, then the colour assigned to   u should not be the colour assigned to v.
So, the question that we were asking in that   map colouring problem is, what is the 
smallest set of colours that we need?   So, there is a very famous theo

64fed5ab-064a-4516-862f-df90fb4888fc.title: Introduction to Graphs
64fed5ab-064a-4516-862f-df90fb4888fc.chunk:
rem in graph 
theory, which says that if you have what is called   a planar graph, so planar graph is something 
which you can draw without any crossing edges. So,   if you go back to the graph that we had before, 
you will notice that in this thing, there

8f0d6960-5e71-4be5-8165-41050e11c389.title: Introduction to Graphs
8f0d6960-5e71-4be5-8165-41050e11c389.chunk:
are no,   so here we have an edge, which is crossing.

the same edge. So, remember, we said that we can   modify this graph, so long as we do not change 
anything, which

241b22a9-acc4-4511-b3f8-741d55c702c5.title: Introduction to Graphs
241b22a9-acc4-4511-b3f8-741d55c702c5.chunk:
is intrinsic to the graph.   So, we can take that edge and move it 
to the outside of the graph. Edges do   not have to be straight lines, they are just 
something which connects vertices together.
  And now, I claim that we have the same graph 
in which

7c487a98-ac09-45cf-80d2-7b4135880341.title: Introduction to Graphs
7c487a98-ac09-45cf-80d2-7b4135880341.chunk:
no two edges cross on the paper.   So, if you can draw a graph like this,

map a physical map of countries or states, and you   take the graph that we constructed b

02cf35c8-d066-4305-aa60-dbf5cb61c5c7.chunk:
ased on the 
borders, it is going to be a planar graph. And it   turns out that for planar graphs, graphs which can 
be drawn without having edges crossing each other,   you can colour such graphs, always with four 
colours. If it is not planar, this is no

2b8c71a6-93b3-4886-a24e-913eb0c42721.title: Introduction to Graphs
2b8c71a6-93b3-4886-a24e-913eb0c42721.chunk:
t true.

question to ask, what is the minimum number of   colours? And it is one of these problems for

this? B

71a5f55b-f36d-4f83-935f-0bfabbc5e3f4.chunk:
ecause colouring seems to be derived   from this map question. And for the map question,

reduced to graph colouring.

hown from left to right.

ence   class does not overlap with a math class. So, now

p

articular scenario is how many classrooms will   we need so that no two classes are scheduled in

4bbe63b9-2492-471d-9e24-992f0b7fedb2.chunk:
our classes. So, we could have an

almost any institution, the num

ber of classes   or courses which are taught will obviously

so what is the minimum number of rooms that

we need in order to schedule the classes the

two classes which

3a071590-70d9-49d6-a634-676b9ec9f07e.chunk:
overlap, and therefore,   they must fall into different classrooms, because 
they cannot share a classroom. The classrooms   themselves are the colours. So, now if two edges 
or two classes are connected by an edge, then they   cannot be assigned the same

5b6c7ce9-ac7f-4250-917d-c7cda66dd8b8.title: Introduction to Graphs
5b6c7ce9-ac7f-4250-917d-c7cda66dd8b8.chunk:
classroom.
So, if classrooms are colours,   they cannot be assigned the same colour. 
So, the edges here represent this overlap,   so that we mentioned above, so these edges, so for 
notice that there is no overlap between these two   pairs. So, there is n

o edge here. And there 
is no edge here because Maths ends before   History and Science both start, but History 
and Science overlap with each other.
  Now, as for our colouring algorithm, we are 
allowed to use the same colour for this note as   either th

0151097b-a888-4e34-b20d-5ebb069fb619.title: Introduction to Graphs
0151097b-a888-4e34-b20d-5ebb069fb619.chunk:
is node or this node because they are not 
connected. So, one possible way of reducing the   number of classrooms here is to reuse the green 
classroom for Maths that we are going to later   use History. We could also equivalently reuse the 
grey classroom

8605bac3-b7a2-4aee-841c-79094e385bc5.title: Introduction to Graphs
8605bac3-b7a2-4aee-841c-79094e385bc5.chunk:
that we use for Science. So, this   is a situation where we can make do with three 
colours, even though we have four classes.
  And of course, if you have a more complicated 
trade you, then it is a more interesting   question to ask how many minimum cla

8a9cdd97-3a17-458d-b6d1-f333be4bd568.chunk:
ssrooms 
you need to have in order to fit that schedule,   or you have to change the schedule to adapt 
to the number of classes because of course,   you cannot change the number of rooms very easily. 
So, you can change the schedule. So, you might   have

74398445-121c-4d38-b411-a11757fb211b.title: Introduction to Graphs
74398445-121c-4d38-b411-a11757fb211b.chunk:
to change the schedule in order to make it 
fit within the infrastructure that you have.
 
  So, let us look at another problem. So, here is a 
problem, which is to do with security cameras. So,   as you know, security cameras are placed in 
such a way tha

8be4c0ea-aabc-4dea-8f0d-2d1a20405011.title: Introduction to Graphs
8be4c0ea-aabc-4dea-8f0d-2d1a20405011.chunk:
t they capture as much of the   surroundings as they can and you want to 
minimize the number of security cameras.   So, supposing you are in a hotel and the hotel 
has corridors, you would ideally place your   cameras at intersections of corridors, let us

901496e3-8227-41f3-a249-ddbc4cfe1f2e.title: Introduction to Graphs
901496e3-8227-41f3-a249-ddbc4cfe1f2e.chunk:
assume that the camera can rotate around and   see all the corridors which meet at a point.
So, a camera can monitor all the corridors. So, if   supposing you have a lift here, and then after you 
come out of the lift you have say corridors which   look

f6c23134-999f-47c6-aeed-b72eea6224ec.title: Introduction to Graphs
f6c23134-999f-47c6-aeed-b72eea6224ec.chunk:
like this, then if you place a camera at 
this point it can see all these three corridors. 
  So, this is the kind of placement that 
we want. So, what is the minimum number   of cameras that you need, if you know the 
layout of the corridors in your hotel

87c9e1ed-2b04-406f-9ef4-6a0b7015dd54.title: Introduction to Graphs
87c9e1ed-2b04-406f-9ef4-6a0b7015dd54.chunk:
.
 
  So, here we would like to represent the floor 
plan as a graph. So, the intersections now   become the meeting points of these corridors. 
So, the actual intersections of your corridors   become the vertices. And now from each vertex, we 
said that i

0875fdd1-e4a2-455d-9af6-6ef198932c9c.title: Introduction to Graphs
0875fdd1-e4a2-455d-9af6-6ef198932c9c.chunk:
f we put a camera here, for instance,   it can monitor all these three, all these 
four corridors. So, the edge represents   a corridor, which is incident at an intersection, 
and this edge says that there is a corridor,   which goes from intersection V2

a29d7cd9-2d8b-4036-af3a-73dd0a47d386.title: Introduction to Graphs
a29d7cd9-2d8b-4036-af3a-73dd0a47d386.chunk:
to intersection V3. And now the   question is, where should we put our cameras?
 
So, this says, we must choose some vertices. So,   supposing I choose V2, then V2 covers all of 
these. But I want to monitor every corridor   in my hotel. So, from V2, I can

087628f9-c59e-4db3-a610-e4f5dfb2e25b.title: Introduction to Graphs
087628f9-c59e-4db3-a610-e4f5dfb2e25b.chunk:
not monitor this 
particular corridor. So, I need to add one more   camera. So, I could put like V0 or at V1. So, 
let me put it V1. So, if I now place my cameras   at V2 and V1, then every corridor on this map is 
monitored. So, this is what is called a v

961c670b-49d6-444f-ba2c-893ce1b68488.title: Introduction to Graphs
961c670b-49d6-444f-ba2c-893ce1b68488.chunk:
ertex   cover, it is a set of vertices, such that 
every edge has one endpoint in the set.
  So, either one end or the other end of 
the edge must be in the set. So, every   endpoint every corridor is monitored by 
one of these cameras. And the question

678b49a1-5f8c-4add-9878-5870a13dfbc7.title: Introduction to Graphs
678b49a1-5f8c-4add-9878-5870a13dfbc7.chunk:
here computationally is again, of course, I 
can put a camera everywhere. And then I will   obviously cover all the corridors. But what is the 
smallest number of intersections that I need to   place cameras at or in other words, what is the 
smallest vert

2bfd780d-a77f-47f9-9f08-7b82c95ecb7a.title: Introduction to Graphs
2bfd780d-a77f-47f9-9f08-7b82c95ecb7a.chunk:
ex cover that I can achieve?
 
  A related problem is what is called an independent 
set. So, here, let us look at this scenario.   So, we have a kind of Fine Arts Academy, which 
can put up various cultural programs including   some group dances. Now, in

85ff2fa0-320c-432d-becf-2ef64c7f8cb2.title: Introduction to Graphs
85ff2fa0-320c-432d-becf-2ef64c7f8cb2.chunk:
a group dance, 
of course, a number of people are involved.   And it could be that some dancers are trained 
to dance and more than one group dance.   So, suppose that this academy wants to put up a 
cultural program, each dance requires the person   perfo

d2187c83-b568-4e73-9813-69f0120e6978.title: Introduction to Graphs
d2187c83-b568-4e73-9813-69f0120e6978.chunk:
rming to wear some elaborate costume.
So, it is not feasible for a dancer to take   part in two dances in the same evening because 
he or she will have to change their costume   and that will be very problematic. So, now, 
you want to know, given the perfo

a38f005b-5344-4ed0-ac5b-4427a46fbe80.title: Introduction to Graphs
a38f005b-5344-4ed0-ac5b-4427a46fbe80.chunk:
rmers who are   available and the dances that are available, what 
is the maximum number of dances you can schedule   in this program, so that you never have to take 
a dance from one dance, and have them change   their costume and take part in another dan

c65e60bc-b01e-42b4-b180-c003434f8061.title: Introduction to Graphs
c65e60bc-b01e-42b4-b180-c003434f8061.chunk:
ce.
So, in this case, again, you can represent each   of the dances as a vertex. And you can say 
that two dancers are connected if they need   one person to participate in both, so if 
they have a common member in that group,   then they are connected. So

c85d3037-b32f-4b44-90e0-8a7a71dfb5b1.title: Introduction to Graphs
c85d3037-b32f-4b44-90e0-8a7a71dfb5b1.chunk:
, here it says that V3 
and V7 for instance, somebody will is required,   who will participate in both of them. Similarly, 
say V5 and V6, but there is no connection between   V6 and V8. So, anybody who takes part in V6 is 
guaranteed not to be part of V8

a0b82b59-4fb3-4813-8bf4-187535f5c624.title: Introduction to Graphs
a0b82b59-4fb3-4813-8bf4-187535f5c624.chunk:
and so on. So, in   this case, we want to find out what is the maximum 
number of dances we can simultaneously schedule   on a day so that there is no such overlap.
 
So, here is one such allocation, supposing we   choose V4, then we cannot schedule these

5b76e24c-ee6c-4804-81c7-bc0210cec825.title: Introduction to Graphs
5b76e24c-ee6c-4804-81c7-bc0210cec825.chunk:
dances because they have some overlap.   On the other hand, there is no overlap with 
V7, so we can take V7, so V7 will rule out V6,   but it does not rule out V5. And if we have done 
V4, V5, and V7, we still have the possibility of   V2 because V2 is no

17dcb60a-6160-4223-815e-4fb794697095.title: Introduction to Graphs
17dcb60a-6160-4223-815e-4fb794697095.chunk:
t connected to any of these.
So, these vertices, now unlike our previous   situation, where the vertices are trying 
to cover all the edges, here, we are saying   these vertices should be mutually disjoint from 
each other, no two vertices that we choose,

02d38376-18df-46f4-9e30-0d4b4d7390e1.title: Introduction to Graphs
02d38376-18df-46f4-9e30-0d4b4d7390e1.chunk:
no two dances that we choose must be connected 
because they should not share a participant.
  So, in this case, we have found four such 
and this is called an independent set. So,   we want the largest number of dances earlier, 
we wanted the smallest n

93772754-8def-41ce-a7f4-bcbba3379870.title: Introduction to Graphs
93772754-8def-41ce-a7f4-bcbba3379870.chunk:
umber of cameras. So,   that was the smallest vertex cover. Here, we want 
the largest number of dances that we can choose   simultaneously in a day is program. So, 
this is the maximum independent set.
 
  Finally, let us look at a very important problem,

9059d01d-d987-4494-9f5b-09342566c277.title: Introduction to Graphs
9059d01d-d987-4494-9f5b-09342566c277.chunk:
which is called Matching. And suppose we have   a class project we are going to assign. And we 
allow groups of two students to do this project   together. But we know that for two students 
to do this together, they must be friends,   if they do not get

0497ebf9-48ff-40d6-8dc7-1ee9a86653ff.title: Introduction to Graphs
0497ebf9-48ff-40d6-8dc7-1ee9a86653ff.chunk:
along with each other, 
there is no point assigning them to a group.
  So, we have a graph like the one on 
the right describing the friends.   So, it says that V2 is a friend of V4, but 
for instance, V2 is not a friend of V3,   because there is no edge

179b8029-2aca-4561-9642-af21253de8fd.title: Introduction to Graphs
179b8029-2aca-4561-9642-af21253de8fd.chunk:
there. What we want to 
know is how many groups can be formed from this,   so that we only pick pairs, which are friends. 
So, we want to find a good allocation.   So, this is a subset. So, the allocation that 
we pick will be a subset of the edges.
  And

c48a3ad7-65dd-4fb6-959a-0ec807ee1407.title: Introduction to Graphs
c48a3ad7-65dd-4fb6-959a-0ec807ee1407.chunk:
once we pick this subset, those will form the 
groups and if we have any person who is not paired   up with another person, that person will have to 
work on their own. So, maybe this is a complicated   project. And we would ideally like most people to 
wo

1e8005ba-d009-4e4e-86c7-05c0f052b106.title: Introduction to Graphs
1e8005ba-d009-4e4e-86c7-05c0f052b106.chunk:
rk in groups, we want to find the largest such.   So here, for instance, is what is called a 
maximal matching. So, I have paired up these two,   I have paired up these two, I cannot pair 
up now 5 with anybody because the only   thing five can be paired u

2d4dbad9-5d80-43d1-a5aa-916af25271c6.chunk:
p with this 4 who is 
already part of another pair and same with 3,   3 can only be paired up with 1 and 4.
So, this matching is maximal in the sense   that I cannot add any more edges and make it 
a larger matching from what I have right now.   But it tur

05fc70f5-553c-46a0-ae6f-340b56f81210.chunk:
ns out that this is not a maximum 
matching the sense that this says we can form   two groups of two and then two people are 
left alone, but maybe in the six people we   can form three groups of two so that everybody 
has a pair and yes, indeed it is poss

2ce2f3d7-b997-4d22-8a97-a3041372bbcc.title: Introduction to Graphs
2ce2f3d7-b997-4d22-8a97-a3041372bbcc.chunk:
ible.
 
  So, we can pair up 5 to 4, 3 to 1, and 0 to 2 as 
we see here. Now everybody is assigned a pair and   now everybody is covered. So, in this particular 
case is quite easy to say that if you have an even   number of vertices and you have half as m

b32fb5dc-c1d2-4f95-bfac-c8a7b06007b9.title: Introduction to Graphs
b32fb5dc-c1d2-4f95-bfac-c8a7b06007b9.chunk:
any edges 
in the matching that everybody is covered. So,   in general, this could be a question which is 
if I give you such a graph, and I asked you to   match up pairs with this constraint, then what is 
the largest matching that you can construct.

1162a9a4-9571-4abe-8bf7-0397b386b807.title: Introduction to Graphs
1162a9a4-9571-4abe-8bf7-0397b386b807.chunk:
So, to summarize, graphs are very interesting 
because they express relationships, many flexible   types of relationships in a very concise way. 
Graphs can be directed as we saw or undirected.   So, when an undirected graph really every edge 
has a matchi

b1223ed4-65eb-4e6a-9c4a-bf377eabae94.title: Introduction to Graphs
b1223ed4-65eb-4e6a-9c4a-bf377eabae94.chunk:
ng edge in the reverse direction,   so we can think of it as a single edge which 
has two directions associated with it. One   of the most fundamental questions that we 
need to ask about graphs is reachability.
  Can I get from one node to another node by

179f9dda-c750-4286-b6e3-0a737163a651.title: Introduction to Graphs
179f9dda-c750-4286-b6e3-0a737163a651.chunk:
a 
path which is a sequence of connected edges?   But there are a wide range of other problems 
also, which are not directly called connected   to reachability which are also interesting. So, 
we saw graph colouring, we saw vertex cover, we   saw the inde

d977b00c-f8ef-48b6-88ef-dd50c55d9eca.title: Introduction to Graphs
d977b00c-f8ef-48b6-88ef-dd50c55d9eca.chunk:
pendent set problem, we saw matching. 
So, these are all a variety of problems, which are   interesting computation problems on 
graphs and which have a number of   practical implications. So, we will 
study some of these as we go along.
